affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: In this tutorial we are going to use a large collection of pre-generated
reference files and open them with Xarrayâ€™s new
functionality. This chapter is heavily inspired by
This collection of reference files were generated from the
dataset.  A version of this dataset is hosted on
In total the dataset is roughly
in compressed blob storage, with a single
file per yearly timestep, per variable. Downloading this entire dataset for analysis on a local machine would difficult to say the least. The collection of
reference files for this entire dataset is only

import dask
import hvplot.xarray  # noqa
import pandas as pd
import xarray as xr
from xarray import DataTree
from distributed import Client
from fsspec.implementations.reference import ReferenceFileSystem

text/html.content:
<script type="esms-options">{"shimMode": true}</script><style>*[data-root-id],
*[data-root-id] > * {

  font-family: var(--jp-ui-font-family);
  font-size: var(--jp-ui-font-size1);
  color: var(--vscode-editor-foreground, var(--jp-ui-font-color1));
}

/* Override VSCode background color */
.cell-output-ipywidget-background:has(
  > .cell-output-ipywidget-background > .lm-Widget > *[data-root-id]
),
.cell-output-ipywidget-background:has(> .lm-Widget > *[data-root-id]) {
  background-color: transparent !important;
}
</style>

children.value: dataset is organized by GCM, Scenario and Ensemble Member. Each of these Scenario/GCM combinations is represented as a combined reference file, which was created by merging across variables and concatenating along time-steps. All of these references are organized into a simple

Not all of the GCM/Scenario reference datasets have shared spatial coordinates and many of the have slight differences in their calendar and thus time dimension.
Because of this, these cannot be combined into a single
provides a higher level abstraction where related
are organized into a tree structure where each dataset corresponds to a

# Read the reference catalog into a Pandas DataFrame
cat_df = pd.read_csv(
    "s3://carbonplan-share/nasa-nex-reference/reference_catalog_nested.csv"
)
# Convert the DataFrame into a dictionary
catalog = cat_df.set_index("ID").T.to_dict("records")[0]
In the following cell we create a function
Use Dask Distributed to load the Xarray-Datasets from Kerchunk reference files

children.label: Use Dask Distributed to load the Xarray-Datasets from Kerchunk reference files

children.value: , we are loading 164 reference datasets into memory. Since they are are
datasets the coordinates are loaded eagerly, but the underlying data is still lazy.

children.value: Build an Xarray-Datatree from the dictionary of datasets

children.label: Build an Xarray-Datatree from the dictionary of datasets

children.value: datasets. We can access individual datasets using
syntax. In the cell below, we will access a single dataset from the
Convert a Datatree node to a Dataset

children.label: Convert a Datatree node to a Dataset

children.value: contains a collection of datasets with related coordinates and variables. Using some in-built methods, we can analyze it as if it were a single dataset. Instead of looping through hundreds of
datasets, we can apply operations across the
. In the example below, we will lazily create a time-series.
Visualize a single dataset with HvPlot
